element_texts.text: Completed

Friday Feb. 24 - 1899
Met Mr. Winter,  Gen. Man. B. & N.M. Ry on the train - also Mr. P.H. McGary of Walker. - Dr. Hart and the Supt of the Schools at sub agencies of Leech Lake, called on me at the hotel. Mr. Episcopal minister in charge of the church at the agency and a Chippewa Indian. word crossed out had been to Washington with the Chippewa delegation, and who had just returned from that place, was on the train from Brainerd to Walker. He was invited by Mr. McGary to meet Capt Mercer, the new agent, but he declined - saying "I will meet him soon enough." "I put in some hot shot against Mercer while in Washington". It appears that the Indians are very much opposed to my coming here as
Completed

Captain W.A. Mercer  7th Cavalry
Leech Lake Agency Minn
Feb. 25 '99
Leech Lake Agency
Headquarters at Walker
Minn from Feb. 25 -'99 to
to Apr 7, 1899
Diary -Feb 25 '99
to Apr 7 1899
Completed

Relieved as acting Indian agent-Omaha and Winnebago Agency, Neb. and transferred as acting Indian agent to the new agency to be established at Leech Lake Minn by Special Order No. 3, Head Qrs. of the Army Washington DC Jan 5, 1899.
Completed transfer of property and funds at Omaha and Winnebago Agency Monday Feb 6, 1899. In Omaha, awaiting Instructions, from the 6th to the 20th of Feb. Sioux City en route to Leech Lake - Feb 20 - guests of Mrs Warfield - In St Paul 21,22, and 23 - guests of Mr and Mrs E.J. Cochran - Left St.P.  9 a.m. 24th and arrived at Walker Minn. (Leech Lake) same evening at 5:30 - obtained room and board at the Pameda Hotel.
Completed

The future welfare of these Indians depends upon the outcome. The law is a mistake - The General Land Office has charge of the timber under the treaty with the Indians = a greater mistake was never made.  The land office people from commissioner down have no responsibility or sympathy for or the future welfare of the Indians to look after. The Indian office which has all the responsibility of the Indian - has no control over his vast resources in timber and land upon which his present and future depends The Indian Office and the G.L.O. are at loggerheads on this subject.  The Indian Office is right.
Completed

(continued)
- got a good 40 ft boat - 20 H.P. engine - with small cabin.
Joined Carrie in Chicago at 4.3o p.m. at Palmer House.  Attended theater in the evening "Jolly Musqueteers" Snowing hard.
Mrch. 31 - Friday - more snow Purchased music box - Lyon and Heally - attended theatre in evening - "Sporting Life."
April 1 - snowing hard Left Chicago 6.30 p.m.
April - 2 arrived St. Paul 7:45 a.m. attended church with the Cochrans with whom we are staying.
April 3 - 
In St. Paul
Completed

Mch. 22   Wednesday
visited reservation -
Putting up ice - 26 inches thick
-@50 c per ton.  Letter from Senator Nelson - will meet him in St. Paul next week to answer about the agency. 
Mch 23
at Walker  Visited agency site
Mch 24
at Walker Minn
Mch 25
at Walker
Mch 26
at Walker
Visited agency and surrounding site
Completed

Mch 27   snow
At Walker - visited agency - new agency site
Mch 28 Tuesday - snow
left for Racine Wis. to buy boats - Stopped over in St Paul called at Merchants hotel on Senator Nelson - failed to see him
Ed Cochran not at train so went up to his house. [Utro Werner] with me
Mch 29 Still at St Paul  visiting Cochran - Called on Senator Nelson again but missed him.  Took 8.10 p.m. train on C. Mil and St. P Ry for Racine Wis.
Mch 30 Arrived at Racine at 830 a.m.  Utro W. went through to Chicago - Made purchase of boats  $18000 - & two row boats $50
Completed

April 4 -  Tuesday
Left St Paul 9 a.m. arrived Walker 6 p.m. very cold, Telegram saying Judge Brubaker is dead
April 5
Visited agency & mill site
April 6  Very pleasant  The first bright pleasant day for weeks.  Visited agency and mill site  Have the engine 
on the ground and all one needs is to put it in place.
April 7  Pleasant - unclear
& bright
Visited mill site & agency  Indians getting in logs
Completed

April 8   Saturday
round rust marking at bottom of page
written upside down at bottom of page

* Ayer MS 3181
Completed

seen them they are doubtless prejudiced by what has been told them by designing persons who are afraid that my coming here in charge will interfere with their schemes or perquisites.  As Gus Beaulieu- mixed blood Chippewa, was a member of the delegation of which the minister was a member, I imagine some critizisms of me

came from him. (G. B.) who is a friend and defender of James I Coffey, a mixed blood half breed of Fond Du Lac reservation with whom I had much trouble while at 

La Pointe Agency - Coffey, I consider a mortal enemy and one would do anything he could to injure me or to influence the Indians against me. He, Coffey is one of the greatest rascals who ever went unhung and I hope for his sake as well as mine that he may never
Completed

cross my path. The adverse feeling among the Indians is most unjust and contrary to the feeling I entertain toward them.  I desire to prove a friend to them - to help them in every worthy project looking to the betterment of their condition and their advancement in civilization.   I know they have been shamefully neglected and unfairly treated and I come here with a desire to straighten out their troubles and do all I can for them.  It is therefore not strange that I consider the act of Rev.      in doing all he can to injure me before he had ever seen me as, uncalled for, unjust and not Christian like.  I shall tell him so when I get
Completed

acquainted with him.

I go into detail here as the diary should show the feeling of the Indians at this time -- Last October the Pillagar Band of Chippewas became hostile and threatening -- a company of the 3rd US. Infantry - with Major Wilkinson of the 3rd Inf. and a newly appointed lieutenant in command of the company came here in obedience to War Dept. orders. Col. Bacon of the Cavalry-Brig. Gen. of volunteers - Cmding the Dept of Dakotas was also with the soldiers. The soldiers were ambushed at Sugar Point opposite Bear Island and the Indians firing from the thick underbrush killed Major Wilkinson, & six soldiers and wounded twelve. It  has not been learned that any Indian was killed or even
Completed

wounded. The troops drew off - the Commissioner of Indian Affairs (a kind hearted, honest man) arrived -- the Indians surrendered - were afterwards arrested but at the earnest request of their many sentimental friends expressed in more earnest petitions to the President - they were not even tried for killing the troops but pardoned and the sentences received for resisting arrest by U.S. Marshals - (the culminating cause of the outbreak) -- were mitigated and they all came back here free -  to glory over their escape from all punishment for armed opposition to U.S. authority and to brag of how many soldiers they killed. The effect has
Completed

been bad - for they now feel that they have whipped the army and can do it again and there are many reports that they are "wild and ugly".
Feb. 25, - '99. Saturday, cold
Received a letter from the Indian Office confirming my journey here and asking me to make a general inspection for agency & school sites and to investigate the conditions on all sides and keep him advised as to the situation. Mr McGary brings me further reports of the ugly feeling among the Indians and that they are espicially displeased with the coming of an army officer for Agent. I do not believe all of this -- but think there is some foundation for the rumors
Completed

(Feb 25 - continued)
Dr. Hart told me last night that a few days ago a number of drunken Indians took his captain of police and locked him up overnight -- It is evident that they need discipline and certainly I can not or will not permit such lack of respect to the constituted authorities. I, of course, have no authority until the agency is established by act of Congress -- the bill now being in conference with the prospect of it becoming a law any day. 
Met a Mr. Gardner (who owns the drug store. jewelry store. and bank, all in one room.) He is an enthusiastic fisherman & hunter and says there is the best of both sports here.
Completed

Feb. 26 - Sunday - Cold, Snowing.
Met several citizens of Walker and all are pleasant. Had a call from Mr. Barnard the editor and publisher of the local paper -- who assures me of his friendship and support.
It seems that Dr. Hart's  friends rather resent my appointment as Agent and that he rather expected it -- From this source, I am told, the ministers opposition comes.
Feb. 27, Monday - Cold
Nothing of interest today
weather cold slight snow.
Feb. 28 - Tuesday -- Cold & clear
Visited the proposed site of new boarding school and think it
Completed

page 18
Sec 19 - T. 142 . R. 30
suitable -- It contains a fine spring with flow enough to supply the whole school -- Should be pumped to tank or container 80' piped to buildings. Also visited several places with Mr. McGary & Supt Cressman who were with me - thought desirable places for an Agency, but they were either too hilly  or the land was allotted. I finally selected a place on Agency Bay in Sec. 13 - T. 142 R. 31 which I think will be a fine spot. It is on a bluff 20 ft. above the water -- and the ground is level and covered with a thick growth of Norway and White Pine. The portage I will have turned into a water thoroughfare or canal.
Completed

page 19
It was pretty tough tramping about in 8 in of snow -- the thermometer below  zero but the necessity for early action on the building is pressing.
March 1, Wednesday
Nothing of Interest.
Later -- Met Mr. Schneider-Auditor of the Brainerd & N. Minn. Ry. -- also a lumberman from Minn. -- named Mullins. --Busy with correspondence & plans for building.
March 2, Thursday
Dr. Hart told me of Gen Beaulieu & the newspaper article - etc.
Busy with office work & plans for building -
Mch, 3. Friday -
Busy with correspondence & plans.
Mr. Lang agrees to put up ice for agency @ 50 cts a ton. - Ice now over 3 feet thick & fine

                                                                                    -- clear & hard as a crystal
Completed

20
March, 4, Saturday
Is the last day of Congress and the Indian Bill must now be a law -- I am anxious to hear the order issued formalysic establishing the agency and to receive information as to the appropriation for Agency & school buildings and boats etc.
Having determined in Nov. '98 to send me here and to establish a new agency--to take in Leech Lake, Winnibigoshish, Cass Lake, Chippewa and Oak Point reservations here -- and Red Lake reservation further north -- and the President having directed my detail on Jan 5 - '99.  -- it is a long time to "hang in the air" waiting for Congress to act. -- before doing anything more - Well, I suppose by the
Completed

21
end of March -- we shall have the new agency matter well settled. -- Visited site of new agency with Mrs Mercer, Cressman, & Surveyor Canfield -- think it best to move the school on this site
March 5th Sunday, Very cold
Busy with correspondence - Answered E I. Cochran - letter asking Mrs. M & I to come to St Paul for two or three days -- wants me to meet a Mr. Eden - Gener'l Frt agent E. M. RR. - theater - supper etc. -- As I have not rec'd notice from the Indian Office -- I can go very well 
and telegraphed him to that effect.
Monday - Mch 6 -- 25-°  very cold
Interviewed carpenters about building. Mr. Lane about ice (50¢ a ton) -- Surveyor about the channels and depth of
Completed

22
of water in lakes thoroughfares, rivers etc. -- Think a launch with not over 2 or 2 1/2 ft. unclear -- and a large centerboard for safety in heavy weather will be the best thing for these waters.
Interview a Mr. [[Procck -- need digger -- driver  will be best -- get a tank from Duluth manufactures. Sup.-Cressman & Surveyor Canfield in - too cold to operate with success.  Dr. Hart from the agency was in - long conference about payments and drunkenness   Thinks G.B is an enemy of mine and will be at the bottom of all trouble - on the reservation  It is plain that the Indians must be taught discipline temperance with respect toward Government authority. I expect
Completed

23
trouble - but will insist upon temperance and suspension of drunken riots. It appears that no agent has ever attempted to control these Indians at all. 
Tuesday March 7 1899
Busy on plans for buildings
Wednesday Mch 8, 1899
Busy on plans for buildings
Thursday Mch 8, 1899
Same - Visited proposed schools site and agency site.  Think I have found one a little better just north 100 yds.
Friday Mch 10  1899
Busy on plans.  Have applied for authority to run the saw mill. I
Completed

29
I had a long talk with Bunga -- & pleasant words with Flaremouth & empty parenthesis the unclear chief of the Pillagers. -- unclear for agency.
Mch - 19. Sunday -18
Very cold &  unclear go over is dear Rev. Willis died serving at the  unclear agency --- Rev. Willis is from this Earth -- belongs to Red Lake & is fiereing Rev. Giefieam unclear while he is agent sick.--
Birthday -- 44 years old.
Mch 20 -- Monday -- Very cold -- 10o
unclear -- 
Many reports in newspapers to the effect that the Indians would break out as soon as the ice went out.
Completed

30
Mch 2, Tuesday
When Mr. Lerigg -- member of leave unclear -- Mr. Robinson -- and those those other gentlemen -- They are interested in the new town of Bimidgi (sic) and all are opposed to the sale of this timber under present law. -- There is to be a sale of the less part of the timber lands of Leech Lake Agency -- May 10 -- and the ones who intend to bid are in favor of the sale -- those opposed to it & who believe in a better system of handling this business -- are ordering unsure to postpone the sale. The interests of the Indians and of the people ofcrossed out living  in other aspect is live unclear property in this section of the state are in favor of a different plan.
